title: [rule links] reduce visual clutter
body: It's great that we added the eslint and jscs links for each rule, but I think there's an opportunity here to reduce the visual clutter a bit for easier reading and skimming. I'm proposing moving the links to a comma separated list at the end of the corresponding rule. I feel it's not too difficult to identify which links are eslint vs jscs, but open to discussion on bringing back the labels. before: ^ seeing all that space used for a label and a link makes me :cry: after: @ljharb

title: Arrow functions and parentheses: "good" example in 8.2 does not follow suggestions in 8.4
Why are some rules well defined but turned off (react/jsx-curly-spacing)?
body:
For example the rule [react/jsx-curly-spacing](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/blob/master/packages/eslint-config-airbnb/rules/react.js#L25):

```
    'react/jsx-curly-spacing': [0, 'never', { 'allowMultiline': true }],
```

isn't just set to `0`, but has defined behavior `'never'` and options `allowMultiline`. Does it mean that you recommend this behaviour, but you're not making it error (`2`) in 3.x because it'll break a lot of stuff? Therefore will it become enabled in 4.0.0? Or is it for internal discussion like "we're proposing this rule to look like this, if there are no objections, it'll be enabled with next major release"?

title: Fixed capitalization
body: Bitshift changed to bitshift

title: add WeBox Studio to the organizations list
Fixed minor capitalization change in Hoisting
body: Not sure if it's an actual fix, but just noticed this was the only comment that had capitalization that wasn't a proper noun.

title: add avant to users
body: add avant to style guide

title: Favor stateless functions over classes when there's no state
Fix syntax issue on createClass example
body: Since `createClass` gets an object, you can't use the `method() {}` syntax, but `{method: function()}`.

title: arrow-parens
body: Example should comply with rule `arrow-parens`

title: Lint the readme
body: Don't know if there's already an issue to do this, but @btmills published https://github.com/eslint/eslint-plugin-markdown. So you should be able to lint the readme with the eslint config?

title: Add `prefer-arrow-callback` to ES6 Rules.

labels.name: semver-minor: tighten rules to match guide

body:
This prefers arrow functions as described in https://github.com/airbnb/javascript#8.1

Fixes #665

title: Update "Comparison Operators & Equality" in README.md
body: The guide should be more clear that [] is truthy because arrays are objects. As is, a reader could be confused about this because an empty string will be evaluated as false and it's possible (but not a good idea) to access a string using array-like syntax. It also doesn't help that this array-like syntax is in line with other languages like C where strings ARE arrays, further adding to potential confusion.

title: Add section on nested/multiline ternaries
body: As per this issue: https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/issues/671

title: return indentation on second line?
Add section on nested/multiline ternaries
body: Specifically, prohibiting nested ternaries (to match https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/blob/master/packages/eslint-config-airbnb/rules/style.js#L63-L64) and perhaps discouraging multiline ternaries (not sure if there's a rule for it).

title: Objects: getters and setters?
Remove whitespace before function call parens
body:
Having a space here is a bit distracting for 2 reasons:
1. This rule is about using soft tabs over tabs
2.  `// good` goes against violation of [18.3](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript#18.3) that says "_Place no space before the argument list in function calls and declarations._"

title: Disallow declaration of global variables
body: `'no-shadow': [2, {'builtinGlobals': true, 'hoist': 'functions', 'allow': []}],`

title: setting environments in shared config?
body:
Hey, I'm still getting up to speed on eslint and your implementation of shared config, so apologies if any of this feedback isn't quite right. And I'm happy to generate PRs for anything you think work addressing ...
### `env` configured in 3 files ...
1. [legacy.js](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/blob/master/packages/eslint-config-airbnb/legacy.js)
   
   a. `'browser': true`
   b. `'node': true`
   c. `'amd': false`
   d. `'mocha': false`
   e. `'jasmine': false`
2. [rules/node.js](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/blob/master/packages/eslint-config-airbnb/rules/node.js): `'node': true`
3. [rules/es6.js](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/blob/master/packages/eslint-config-airbnb/rules/es6.js): `'es6': false`
### issues
1. Why is `legacy.js` disabling `amd`, `mocha`, and `jasmine`? Aren't environments off until explicitly enabled?
2. Why is `legacy.js` enabling `browser` and `node`? While these may be the most common usage contexts, that seems to overstep the role of this style-guide-based shared config, which might be used in a variety of circumstances. Even if that weren't the case, any "efficiency" gained in enabling both by default would seemingly be lost when most users then have to disable one or the other. Maybe I'm missing something?
3. Similarly - and this may seem like an odd question - why is `rules/node.js` enabling `node`? The fact that `legacy.js` extends `rules/node.js`, and the fact that everything else extends `legacy.js`, means that `node` is always enabled. If the rules in `rules/node.js` are "safe" to be included everywhere, I think it makes sense to keep that rule set in the chain of extensions, but then I don't think it makes sense for the `env` to be configured in there. If the rules in `rules/node.js` are NOT "safe" to be included everywhere, its place in the extension chain needs to be altered, at which point, it might end up making sense to leave the `env` config in there, similar to how `es6` `env` config makes sense as you have it, in a rule set only included in an extension chain used by those intending to use `es6`.
4. Depending on how you respond to the prior 2 issues, this might be moot, but it seems redundant that `node` `env` is enabled in both `legacy.js` and `rules/node.js`.
